Still processing but THIS HAPPENED! Absolutely honoured to have made the <ORG> 30 Under 30 Asia list❤️🥹 When I took up content creation full time back in 2017, most people didn’t see it as potential career choice. For someone whose life plan had always been to take up a job, like everyone else in my family, working as an independent creator was scary. I didn’t know how much revenue I’d be able to generate each month or how long I’d be able to sustain it for before I’ve to get a “real job”. I still have days when I ask my self if I’m doing enough. If what I’m doing is making any kind of impact and then when I see things like this happen, it just all feels right. In the last few years, I’ve achieved and experienced things I never even dreamt about when I was starting out. I was only doing what made me happy and giving it all I have. THIS is definitely one of those things!❤️ Thank you for being a part of my journey and making crazyyyyy possible 🙋🏻‍♂️

Episode 14 of MICROWAVE MAGIC ✨ A series where I make your favorite desserts at home only in a microwave 🙌🏻 What’s a dessert without a rich, glossy chocolate sauce? 🍫 Whether you’re drizzling it over pancakes, dipping fruits, or pouring it on your brownies, this 2 minute homemade chocolate sauce is an absolute game-changer! Made with just 5 simple ingredients, it’s smooth, velvety, and perfectly chocolatey – all without a stove! Ingredients: 🥛 1/2 cup milk 🍬 6 tbsp sugar 🍫 1/4 cup cocoa powder 🌾 1 tbsp all-purpose flour 🧈 1 tbsp butter Method: 1️⃣ In a microwave-safe bowl, whisk together milk, sugar, cocoa powder, flour, and butter. 2️⃣ Microwave for 2 minutes, whisking every 30 seconds for a silky-smooth texture. 3️⃣ Let it cool slightly & enjoy your thick, glossy chocolate sauce! That’s it! No more store-bought chocolate sauce when you can whip up this quick & decadent version at home. 🍩✨ Save this for your next dessert fix & tag a friend who needs this! 💌

Fasting, but make it sweet! ✨ These Sabudana Waffles are light, crispy, and naturally sweetened with honey/maple syrup—perfect for a guilt-free <ORG> treat! Try this unique vrat-friendly twist and satisfy your sweet cravings. Recipe: Ingredients: • 1 cup sabudana (tapioca pearls), soaked for 4-5 hours • 1 small boiled potato, mashed • ¼ cup milk (or coconut milk for a dairy-free option) • 2 tbsp honey or maple syrup • ½ tsp cardamom powder • 1 tbsp almond flour (optional, for a nuttier texture) • 1 tbsp ghee (for greasing) • Chopped nuts & saffron strands for garnish Method : 1. In a bowl, mix soaked sabudana, mashed potato, milk, honey/maple syrup, cardamom, and almond flour. 2. Preheat your waffle iron and lightly grease with ghee. 3. Pour the batter and cook until golden and crispy (about 5-7 minutes). 4. Garnish with chopped nuts and saffron strands. 5. Serve warm with extra honey or maple syrup for drizzling! - - - 💕

Crispy Sabudana Tikki – <ORG>! 🔥✨ 💥 Fasting? No problem! Feasting? ABSOLUTELY! These golden, crispy <ORG> are the perfect blend of crunch and melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Serve them with chilled yogurt or spicy green chutney, and you’ve got a that’ll make your taste buds do the garba! 💃🎶 ✨ <ORG> this recipe for festive cravings! ✨ 🔹 Ingredients: ✔ 1 cup sabudana (soaked for 4-5 hrs) ✔ 2 boiled potatoes (mashed) ✔ ½ cup crushed peanuts ✔ 1-2 green chilies (finely chopped) ✔ ½ tsp sendha namak (rock salt) ✔ ½ tsp cumin powder ✔ 1 tbsp chopped coriander ✔ 1 tsp lemon juice ✔ Ghee or oil for shallow frying 🔹 How to Make It: 1️⃣ Mix all the ingredients in a bowl and form small tikkis. <ORG> ghee in a pan and shallow-fry until crispy and golden brown. <ORG> hot with vrat-friendly chutney & enjoy! 📍Tag a fasting foodie who NEEDS this in their life! 💕

We didn’t touch down in Goa searching for meaning. No big plans. No breakthrough moments. Just a pause. Me and my boys. Unfiltered, unrushed, and fully ours. What we found at <ORG> wasn’t just luxury — It was room to reset. Room to notice each other without the noise. Not as a parent on autopilot or kids caught in routines — But simply as three people, present. We swam until time slipped away with the tide. We hand-fed geese and watched wonder unfold in their eyes. We wandered through green paths that felt like stories — Every branch a whisper, every leaf a teacher. The chefs even brought the magic into the kitchen — inviting the kids in for hands-on sessions, where dough turned into laughter and recipes became memories. And somehow… we never once looked at the clock. And the food — It wasn’t just a meal. It was memory, served warm. Delicate crab, smoky snapper, buttery lobster — Every plate carried intention. The chefs weren’t just preparing dinner. They were pouring soul into silence. No itinerary. No pressure. Just honest moments held gently together — And a team of butlers and chefs extraordinaires who redefined what it means to truly care. Between barefoot dinners, tangled sheets, sea salt on our skin, and steaming mugs of cocoa — I caught a glimpse of who my sons are becoming. And in that softness, maybe… I found a new piece of myself too. This wasn’t a stay. This was an arrival. { st regis goa, goa travel, Goa with kids, family travel, sikh family, goa vacation, family bonding, real moments, authentic experiences, travel with kids, slow travel, luxury travel, beach vacation, nature walk, seafood, goa diary, travel memories }

On our Visit The USA journey through Washington State, we did something that felt so real, so local, so Seattle — we took <ORG> with <ORG>. Just us, our daughter Rut Suhavi, and our parents… walking, talking, tasting, and soaking in the energy of this incredible neighborhood. It wasn’t about fancy restaurants — it was about real flavors, real stories. From Korean-Hawaiian comfort at Marination to tangy ginger fizz at Rachel’s, sourdough bagels at <ORG>, and honest, hearty Middle Eastern bites at Mamnoon Street — every stop felt like a warm hug from Seattle. What made it special wasn’t just what we ate, but the way we experienced it — as a family, learning, laughing, sharing memories over bites that felt like home in a faraway land. And guiding us through it all was the warm and knowledgeable Chef Eric Olinsky, who brought each story to life. If you’re ever in Seattle, take this walk. Taste the city. Talk to the people. Let it surprise you.

<ORG> has a way of slowing you down—and it’s pure bliss. At Jawakara Islands, part of <ORG>, we felt the world melt away. Our days kicked off with fresh coconuts on the beach and wrapped up with barefoot dinners under a sky full of stars. We cycled through palm-shaded paths, sailed into breathtaking horizons, snorkeled over vibrant coral gardens, and let the salty ocean air weave its quiet magic. The spa days, the jaw-dropping sunsets, the serene stillness—it all hit us right in the soul, reminding us what true ease feels like. Jawakara blends luxury with heart. It’s elegant, warm, and built for moments that stick with you. We arrived as a family and left with memories we’ll treasure forever. <ORG>, you gave us a slice of paradise we didn’t even know we were craving.

A Timeless Winter at <ORG>, St. Petersburg, Russia 🇷🇺 St. Petersburg is a city built on vision, and <ORG> stands as a tribute to that legacy. Designed by Domenico Trezzini, the architect behind Peter the Great’s grand vision for the city, this palace embodies the elegance and ambition of early 18th-century Russia. Walking through its stately halls, I couldn’t help but feel transported back in time. The intricate Baroque details, the antique furniture, and the soft glow of chandeliers reflect a history carefully preserved. From its foundations along the Neva River to the stories embedded in its walls, <ORG> carries the spirit of a city once shaped by emperors and artists. Winter only adds to the magic. The snow outside, the warmth of this grand palace, and the feeling of being wrapped in history—this is what makes travel truly special.

Saddle up for a family adventure like no other! 🐎✨ At <ORG> Mount Kenya Safari Club, we’re taking in the fresh air, open spaces, and the simple joy of being together. Horses have always been a part of Sikh history, making this experience even more special. Grateful for these little moments that make the journey so memorable. 💙🌿

MY UNTOLD STORY: It wasn't that easy for me to keep long hair, people start judging you & pass several comments. But then when you know your goal nothing can shake your determination without giving any explanation to others. Thanks to <ORG> for the inspiration and for making me realize that it's not about how old you are to make a difference in someone's life but it's all about your intentions. My best wishes to you Ryan for everything in life. People keep questioning about my long hair to my parents & after 2 years I told my parents about the hair donation and asked them to keep it as a secret. So noone except my parents knew about it. Last year in 2022 I decided to cut my hair since I got the desired length for donation but due to my selection of <ORG> I couldn't cut my hair & these long hair with a man bun became my identity. After the show random people used to recognize me due to these long hair. After researching I decided to donate my hair to <ORG> staffs for making this process easier and special thanks to who supported this cause. Date: 12.08.2023 Place: Hair stylist: Filmed by : Thanks for documenting the moment so well.

▪︎During summer vacation after the evening play was about to get over we used to steal raw mangoes from our neighborhood trees. Where aiming & throwing stones or using sticks to <ORG> eating small raw mangoes with <ORG> chilli powder was the best thing. ▪︎Biologically known as Mangifera Indica, mango is packed with the goodness of nutrients such as vitamin C, fiber, iron, folate, copper, magnesium to name a few. ▪︎These nutrients help in boosting immunity, improving heart health and balancing hormonal imbalance, strengthening metabolism. Benefits of raw mango: ● Kill the intense summer heat. ●Helps in digestive problem. ●Lower the risk of cancer. ●Prevent dental problems. ●Supports eye health. ●Reduce the risk of blood disorders.

▪︎Summers with these bitter but beautiful bundle of goodness that I foraged during early morning near our house. ▪︎Neem tree is found in every part of our country that belongs to the family <ORG>. ▪︎Few year back I shared a post on neem flowers, its benefits & a recipe which is commonly prepared in Odia homes. ▪︎Neem tree is used in traditional medicines and all its products are widely used in the treatment of various external & internal health conditions. ▪︎All parts of the tree be its flowers, bark, stem, <ORG> are incorporated into the formulations of medicines, soaps, cosmetics, toothpaste & mosquito repellants.

▪︎Once upon a time though it was underrated, but now this culinary delight is known for its amazing cooling effect on the stomach during summers. ▪<ORG>'s a power-packed probiotic dish made with leftover rice & also fresh rice. Yes I am talking about "PAKHALA"(Water Rice). It is also popular in many other states with different names. ▪︎Pakhaḷa is an <ORG> term used for this dish consisting of cooked rice washed or lightly fermented in water. The liquid part is known as Toraṇi. ▪︎Just like in the <ORG> household ,even the lord Jagannath loves Pakhala and also a part of temple cuisine. ▪︎There are so many type of variations of pakhala being consumed in Odisha. ▪︎Consumption of pakhala coincides with mango growing season there is a variation of pakhala known as "AMBA NASI PAKHALA" where the sap of raw mango stems is added with Pakhala. ▪<ORG> may sound weird because mango sap is very <ORG> can cause terrible skin burns but adding the same sap in ‘Pakhala’ gives the dish a typical raw mango aroma & a unique taste. ▪︎Mango sap has anti-microbial properties may make it suitable for use as a preservative & a flavoring agent in food.

After a failed attempt of finding the "Kabadiwala" Who was like a "Godman" for me who came, helped & vanished. Who taught me a lesson of kindness and humanity. I came home with this branch of red silk cotton and did a photo shoot even after a bad weather. I had no plans to do a video shoot looking at the bad lighting & weather. At the same time I had very few buds to cook a dish "Semul ki Sabji" then decided to make some fritters that will give me an idea about the taste & the texture of this edible bud after cooking. Since it was my first time cooking these buds I was very excited. Making fritters is very easy and turns out well. These buds don't have any flavour or taste with slight astringency and a little slimy at the end.

Scientifically known as Butea monosperma. Commonly known as Palash, tesu. The plant grows as a medium-sized tree and is a native to India. They flower from January to March, the tree is laden with orange-vermillion flowers, which also lend it the most famous name'The Tree of the Flame'. Palash is abundantly available in central, <ORG> also other parts of the country. The flower is once used in making dyes for Holi but introduction of chemical colours in the market puts an end to its use. Tribal areas of Maharashtra and adjoining <ORG>, however, once valued palash as the best coolant, with nutritional and healing qualities. While in most areas the tradition of consuming the extract of the flower has died out, it is surviving in small pockets. During summer, cold infusion of the dried flower is consumed as sherbet, while a tea prepared with dried flower can be consumed all year long. Ingredients: Fresh/Dry Palash flowers A large handful of rock sugar: To taste Fennel seeds Method: Soak all the ingredients with 4 glasses of water for 3 to 4 hours or till the flowers lose colour. Stir well, strain and serve chilled. Benefits: Palash flowers are considered anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, anthelmintic, anti-diabetic, diuretic, analgesic, antitumor and astringent. Its leaves are astringent, diuretic and anti-ovulatory properties.

🌊 Fighting Spirit, One Wave at a Time 🌊 As a kid, I was fearless—an athlete through and through. But life threw me a curveball in 2003 when an accident planted a fear of speed in me. Since then, rafting and skiing were two things I just couldn’t bring myself to try. I attempted skiing soon after the accident but backed out, and rafting? I resisted it for years. Until now. I finally told myself, “You’re wearing a life jacket, you’re a certified scuba diver—what could go wrong?” Meeting from was a game-changer. His calm instructions made it all feel so doable. With a mix of nerves and excitement, I stepped into the raft. The first wave hit, and for a second, I was like, “What am I doing?” But then I locked in, held on, and suddenly, I was loving every second. We conquered the Grade 3, 16km stretch, and now I can’t stop thinking—why didn’t I try this sooner? I wish we’d done the Grade 4, 36km route, but hey, there’s always next time! This experience has left me hooked, and Mukesh’s camping and rafting trip is officially on my bucket list. Sometimes, pushing past fear opens up the door to incredible experiences. This one? Hands down, one of the best of my life. 🚣‍♀️💙

🌄 Foodie Finds from <ORG> 🏔️ <ORG> truly stole my heart – and my taste buds! In just 4 days, I came back with some unique flavors that reflect the region’s rich cultural heritage and natural bounty. 🍯💛 First up, the Seabuckthorn Jam – a tart and tangy delight made from the berries that grow wild in the high altitudes of <ORG>. Known for their high vitamin C content, these berries are a local treasure, packed with nutrients and a burst of flavor. 🫐✨ Then there’s <ORG>, a sweet spread made from the region’s famous <ORG>i apricots. These fruits thrive in the harsh climate and are known for their intense sweetness and vibrant color. Apricots have been a part of <ORG>’s food culture for centuries, dried and eaten during the winter months. 🍑 And of course, I couldn’t leave without some Yak Cheese! This traditional cheese, called “Churpi,” is a local staple, made from the milk of the hardy yaks that graze on the high-altitude pastures. It’s rich, slightly tangy, and has a unique texture that makes it perfect for snacking or cooking. 🧀🐂 Four days was definitely not enough to soak in all the flavors this region has to offer! I only wish I could have stayed longer to immerse myself in a <ORG>i home, to truly experience their warmth and cuisine. Next time for sure! 💖

Recipe process in the comments below! <ORG> Ingredients: Herbed Rice: - 1 cup Cooked Short Grain Rice - ½ tablespoon Butter - 1 tablespoon Fresh Coriander, chopped - 2 teaspoons <ORG>, to taste <ORG> tablespoons Oil - 3 tablespoons Almonds, soaked & peeled - 1 small Onion, diced - 3 small Tomatoes, pureed - 2 Kashmiri Red Chillies, soaked in hot water - 3 cloves Garlic, diced - ¼ cup Cream - 1 teaspoon Coriander Powder - 1 teaspoon Chilli Flakes - 1 teaspoon Oregano - 1 teaspoon Cumin Powder - A pinch of Sugar - 1 tablespoon Fresh Coriander, chopped - 2 teaspoons <ORG> and <ORG>, to taste

This Mogra Sabza Cooler is the perfect refreshment for a warm day! A quick blend of floral mogra syrup, butterfly pea tea, and sabza seeds makes for a vibrant, cooling drink ✨All you need is a few simple ingredients and it looks just as gorgeous as it tastes 🪷 Ingredients: For the Mogra Syrup: • ½ cup Sugar • ½ cup Water • 1 tsp Lime Juice • ½ cup Mogra flowers (loosely packed, remove stems) • 3 Cardamom pods For the Sharbat: • 15-30 ml Mogra Syrup • 15-30 ml Lime Juice • 1 cup Water • 1 tsp <ORG> leaves • ½ tbsp Sabza seeds (hydrated in ¼ cup water) • Crushed Ice or Ice Cubes • Mogra flowers (for garnish) Method: 1. Brew the butterfly pea tea in 1 cup of warm water for 1-2 minutes, strain, and set aside. 2. In a saucepan, dissolve the sugar in water over medium heat. Add the cleaned mogra flowers and cardamom pods. <ORG> for 4-5 minutes, allowing the flavors to infuse. Strain and cool the syrup. 3. Soak the sabza seeds in ¼ cup water and let them hydrate for 10-15 minutes. 4. In a glass, add crushed ice, mogra syrup, hydrated sabza, and the brewed butterfly pea tea. Stir everything well. 5. Squeeze a lime wedge over the drink to change the color. Garnish with fresh mogra flowers. Enjoy your refreshing Bluepea Jasmine Cooler!

Celebrate Eid with this rich, flaky, and nutty Baklava! Layers of crisp phyllo pastry, crunchy nuts, and aromatic syrup make this a perfect festive treat ✨ Ingredients - •Phyllo Pastry Sheets - 1/2 a packet (around 18-20 sheets) •Pistachios - 50g •Walnuts - 50g •Castor Sugar - 1/3rd cup •Cinnamon powder - 1/4th teaspoon •Salt - a pinch •Butter/Ghee- 1/2 Cup •Butter for Greasing the Pan Syrup •Sugar - 1 Cup •Water - 3/4th Cup •Lemon Juice - 1 teaspoon •Rose Water - 1/2 teaspoon Process - * Preheat the oven at 180c * In a bowl mix fine chopped <ORG>, castor sugar and cinnamon powder (you can also choose to pulse this mixture in a blender) * Cut the phyllo sheet according to the baking pan size and grease the tin with butter or ghee * Place half of the sheets in the pan (8-10 sheets) and add the nut mix * Spread it out evenly , place the remaining half of the sheets (8-10 sheets) top of it and cover fully * Pour ghee on top of the phyllo sheets * Cut them into a diamond shape with the help of your knife and bake for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown on top and fully baked inside * While the baklava is baking prepare the sugar syrup * Heat water and sugar together , let the sugar dissolve - finish it with lemon juice and rose water * Pour the syrup over the baklava as soon as it comes out of the oven set it aside to cool down * Garnish with pistachios and Enjoy!

Comment “Healthy” for SATTU POWDER AUR SATTU KI CHAAS - Recipe via <ORG> loss recipes Looking for a refreshing and nutritious way to beat the summer heat? Sattu buttermilk is the answer! This twist to traditional buttermilk is not only delicious but also packed with protein, making it the perfect way to stay hydrated and energized during those hot summer days ☀️. Sattu powder which I have created from roasted chana infused with mint leaves flavors; you can even store for 8-10 days in fridge. This cooling beverage is not only a thirst quencher but also aids in digestion and helps in keeping you full for longer. Recipe is so easy - - Take 1/2 cup roasted chana - Remove the skin of roasted chana & take it in a blender jar. - With <ORG>, add a small piece of ginger. - Add 1 green chilli. - And add a small bunch of mint leaves. - Grind everything and make a powder. - Protein packed Sattu powder is ready. You can store it for 10 days in fridge. - Now in a blendar jar, add 1 cup curd. - Add some black salt & roasted cumin seeds powder. - Add 2 tbs of Sattu powder. - Add water as required - Blend everything together - Sattu chaas is ready, serve it chilled & have it everyday for that extra dose of protein . Whether you’re lounging by the pool or hitting the gym, sattu buttermilk is the perfect companion to keep you cool and energized. . https://meghnasfoodmagic.in/recipe/sattu-buttermilk-3/ . Love M

Comment “Moong” for PROTEIN AND <ORG> WITH TAMARIND DRESSING - Recipe via <ORG> 🌱✨ **Are you ready to supercharge your meals with a protein-packed delight?** ✨🌱 <ORG> hello to my *Protein & Fiber Rich Moong Salad with <ORG> Dressing!* This vibrant and nutritious salad is not only delicious but also loaded with goodness that'll keep you energized throughout the day! 💪🥗 **Here’s recipe for this wholesome treat:** 1️⃣ Start by steam cooking 1 cup of pre-soaked (overnight) moong. Remember, don’t throw away that nutrient-rich steamed water; it’s perfect for your dal or khichdi! 🌿 2️⃣ Once cooled, mix in **1.5 cups of finely chopped veggies**—juicy tomatoes, crunchy carrots, zesty onions, colorful bell peppers, and crisp cabbage. 3️⃣ Add in one pomegranate seeds for that juicy burst of flavor, some fresh coriander for brightness, and 1/4 cup of toasted peanuts for that satisfying crunch! 🤤❤️ **Now, let's talk about that delicious tamarind dressing!** 🥄✨ In a bowl, combine **1/4 cup of warm water** with **2 tsp of jaggery**, **1 tbsp of tamarind pulp**, **1 tsp of roasted jeera powder**, **1 tsp of chili flakes**, and a pinch of salt. Shake it all together for a tangy twist that'll elevate your salad to the next level! 🌟 Pour the dressing over your salad just before serving for the ultimate freshness!** [ Protein-rich salad recipes , Moong salad benefits , High fiber salads , Health benefits of moong beans , <ORG> dressing recipes , Vegetarian protein sources , Easy salad recipes , Nutrient-dense meal ideas , Fresh salad ingredients , Plant-based nutrition ] https://meghnasfoodmagic.in/recipe/protein-fibre-rich-moong-salad-with-tamarind-dressing/ Love M

Comment “No Sugar” for - NO SUGAR MANGO MAKHANA CUSTARD - Fasting recipe via <ORG> When someone says you are eating unhealthy or high calorie food during fasting, show them this recipe. It’s no sugar, full of healthy ingredients like <ORG> fresh seasonal fruits and nuts. This custard combines the goodness of Makhana, dates, and fresh seasonal fruits, ensuring you stay full and energized. Makhana, or fox nuts, is not only a powerhouse of protein but also rich in fiber and antioxidants, promoting digestion, heart health, and weight management. And don’t underestimate the power of dates! They're not just naturally sweet; they help with digestion, boost energy, enhance brain function, and support bone health. Recipe - 1. Heat up 1 cup of milk. 2. Add 4-5 elaichi (cardamom) powder and a pinch of soaked saffron. 3. In another bowl, take 5-6 dates (you can adjust as per your taste) and 1 cup of dry roasted Makhana. 4. Pour the hot saffron milk into the bowl with dates and Makhana, then set aside for 30 minutes. 5. Once cooled, blend the mixture until smooth. 6. Refrigerate your creamy custard for 2 hours to thicken further. 7. Serve with fresh fruits and nuts of your choice. This mango season, I recommend fresh mango, pistachios, and cashews.. In this fasting season, this will make you feel full for longer period of time. . https://meghnasfoodmagic.in/recipe/no-sugar-mango-makhana-custard/ . Their cocktail bar adds an extra layer of fun to this unforgettable dining experience! Lastly, make sure to check out **Offtrack**, one of Asia’s Top 50 Bars! Their crispy cauliflower with special Ranch Dressing and mix nuts was an explosion of flavor, and i was so pleasantly surprised seeing sourdough roti with paneer butter jackfruit- a taste sensation I won’t forget! 🥦🍞🥥 So, when in Singapore, don’t miss your greens! Method : Take 1 cup Sabudana, wash it and sprinkle a little Water Cover it and leave for 4-5 hours In a mixing bowl, take 2 medium Potatoes (boiled up to 2-3 whistles) Add soaked Sabudana (keep small amount of sabudana aside) Add 1/2 cup coarsely crushed roasted Peanuts Add 3-4 finely chopped Green Chillies Add a small bunch of chopped Coriander Add some grated Ginger (optional) Add 2 tsp Cumin Seeds (Jeera) Add Salt as per taste Squeeze 1 Lemon and give it a good mix Make small tikki shape vadas Coat them with soaked Sabudana Brush a little <ORG> on a parchment paper lined in an air fryer <ORG> sabudana vadas on it and brush oil on top Air fry for 180⁰ for 20 min (Check after 10 min, flip the vadas and again cook) Enjoy Delicious and Crispy Sabudana Vada with Curd. . https://meghnasfoodmagic.in/recipe/sabudana-vada/ .
